One of the arguments against implementing ranked-choice voting (RCV) is that RCV is harder for voters to participate in. Two of the reasons for this are the more complicated ballot design and the extra effort that goes into forming a ordered preference of candidates. To evaluate this claim, we examine rates of ballot errors and undervoting (ranking fewer than the allowed number of candidates) in some American elections conducted with RCV.
